title: Presidency of William McKinley
added: The McKinley administration brought foreign affairs to the top of the agenda for the first time since the 1840s. Most Republicans supported an expansionist foreign policy, building the American presence in the world that suited its increasing economic dominance. Opposition came from an anti-imperialist element, that include some old time Republicans, as well as most Democrats. However, in 1898 the Democrats took the lead in demanding Spain stop oppressing the independent-minded people of Cuba, while McKinley tried to stop the rush to war. <ref> Frank Ninkovich, "The United States and Imperialism." in Robert D. Schulzinger, ed. ''A Companion to U.S. Foreign Relations'' (2006) pp 79â€“102. </ref>
